learning_outcomes.description: Recognise and understand the meaning of - the mathematical notation for matrices and vectors.
Recognise and understand the meaning of - set notation and mathematical functions, the composition, inverse and the limit of functions.
Recognise and understand the meaning of - the derivative of a function.
Recognise and understand the meaning of - complex numbers represented in cartesian, exponential and polar form.
Recognise and understand the meaning of - the Fundamental Theorem of Algebra, De Moivre's Theorem and the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus.
Recognise and understand the meaning of - integration as the antiderivative of a function and as the limit of a Riemann sum.
Express/manipulate - mathematical ideas using matrix and vector notation.
Express/manipulate - simple functions and represent them graphically.
Express/manipulate - equations involving complex numbers using the complex conjugate and represent a complex number on an Argand diagram.
Calculate - the solution to inequalities and express them graphically.

Calculate - evaluate the limit of a simple function, the derivative of simple functions using the limits formula, the constant multiple, sum, product and quotient rules of differentiation, and the derivative of a relation.
Calculate - critical points of a function, and use the first and second derivative tests to sketch the graph of a function.
Use Riemann sums to estimate the area under a curve and evaluate integrals using substitution, integration by parts, and partial fractions.
Calculate - equations of lines and planes and solve problems concerning lines and planes.
Apply/Model - physical problems using matrices and vectors.
Apply/Model - mathematical induction to prove mathematical statements.
Apply/Model - differentiation and integration to solve applied problems.
Apply/Model - the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus, De Moivre's Theorem and the Fundamental Theorem of Algebra.

assessments.weighting: <dd>15% The best 6 exercises will count for assessment. </dd>
assessments.category: Participation/ Student contribution, Tutorial/ Problem Set
assessments.task_description:
You must attend your practicals in-person. For each practical (except Weeks 1, 2, 3, 5 and 11), you will complete a collaborative exercise containing problems similar to MATH1050 exam questions. Hand in the practical exercise to your tutor at the end of the practical.

There are 8 practical exercises (all weeks except Weeks 1, 2, 3, 5 and 11). The best 6 will count for assessment.

If you are unwell then DO NOT attend your in-person practical. Please attend a different practical during the week.
assessments.submission_guidelines: The exercise is submitted to tutors at the end of the practical.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You cannot defer or apply for an extension for this assessment.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You cannot defer or apply for an extension for this assessment.

assessments.task_description: You must submit detailed written solutions to a collection of mathematical problems.
assessments.submission_guidelines: Submit via Gradescope. Instructions are on Blackboard.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.due_date:
In-semester Saturday

29/03/2025 - 12/04/2025

In-semester Saturday

You must hold all of the following three Saturdays free until the exam date is officially announced

  • 29 March 2025 (Week 5)
  • 5 April 2025 (week 6)
  • 12 April 2025 (week 7)
assessments.task_description:
The closed book examination will be invigilated on-campus for all students.

There will be a range of short-answer and problem solving questions.

Casio FX-82 or Approved calculators may be used. Graphical calculators (that is, calculators with text output or a multi-line display) are NOT allowed.
assessments.submission_guidelines: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to defer this exam.

A formula sheet will be provided.

learning_activities.learning_period: Multiple weeksFrom O-week To Exam week 2(17 Feb - 22 Jun)
learning_activities.topic:
Independent work

During the semester students are expected to work on MATH1050 outside of class time to consolidate the information given during lectures, work on tutorial problem sheets and assignments, complete extra practice problems and study for examinations. This semester you have access to a UQExtend website which contains extra resources. The UQExtend site link is on Blackboard.


Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04, L05, L06, L07, L08, L09, L10, L11, L12, L13, L14, L15, L16, L17, L18

learning_activities.learning_period: Multiple weeksFrom Week 1 To Week 13(24 Feb - 01 Jun)
learning_activities.topic:
Lectures

Lectures define the course material. They set out the basic theory and demonstrate techniques for problem solving. They cover all the core material required for the course. While attending lectures, students are expected to annotate their course notes as the lecturer works through the notes, and complete the examples in the course notes. Students have access to a UQExtend website which contains extra resources (pre-recorded videos, quizzes and interactive animations). The UQExtend site link is on Blackboard.


Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04, L05, L06, L07, L08, L09, L10, L11, L12, L13, L14, L15, L16, L17, L18
